Package org.opensextant.giscore.geometry

Class LinearRing

java.lang.Object
org.opensextant.giscore.geometry.Geometry
org.opensextant.giscore.geometry.GeometryBase
org.opensextant.giscore.geometry.LinearRing
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, Iterable<Point>, IGISObject, VisitableGeometry, IDataSerializable
public class LinearRing extends GeometryBase implements Iterable<Point>
The LinearRing class represents an ordered list of Geodetic2DPoint points for input and output in GIS formats such as ESRI Shapefiles or Google Earth KML files.

A LinearRing is a closed-loop, double-digitized list, which means the first and last point must be the same. This type of object does not exist as a primitive in ESRI Shapefiles. In Google KML files, this object corresponds to a Geometry object of type LinearRing. Note that the topological predicates assume that LinearRings do not wrap around the international date line.

A LinearRing object in itself may be a closed-line (i.e. polyline) shape or the inner/outer boundary of a polygon so depends on the context of the Ring. The first ring in a Polygon container is considered the outer boundary of that Polygon and any other Rings are used as the inner boundary of a Polygon to create holes in the Polygon.

Notes/Restrictions:
-LinearRings can have mixed dimensionality but such rings are downgraded to 2d.
-LinearRing must contain at least 4 Points.
-If validateTopology is selected then constructor enforces that the ring must start and end with the same point and the ring does not self-intersect.
-Portions of the class were taken from the Apache Harmony project and are subject to the Apache license. Those portions were (probably) written by Denis M. Kishenko.

Author:
Paul Silvey

  • Constructor Details

    • LinearRing

      public LinearRing()
      Empty ctor for object io. Constructor must be followed by call to readData() to initialize the object instance otherwise object is invalid.

    • LinearRing

      public LinearRing(List<Point> pts) throws IllegalArgumentException
      This Constructor takes a list of points and initializes a Geometry Object for this Ring. By default, it does not do topology validation. To do validation, use alternate constructor.

      Note points are copied by reference (assuming multiple geometries may share the same list of points for smaller memory footprint) so modifications to point list after constructor called will change the internal state of this instance which may leave object in inconsistent state. Make copy of list if need to modify contents after constructing a LinearRing instance.

      Parameters:
      pts - List of Geodetic2DPoint point objects to use for the vertices of this Ring
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - error if point list is empty or number of points is less than 4

    • LinearRing

      public LinearRing(List<Point> pts, boolean validateTopology) throws IllegalArgumentException
      This Constructor takes a list of points and initializes a Geometry Object for this Ring, performing topology validation if requested.

      Note points are copied by reference so caller must copy lists if need to modify them after this constructor is invoked.

      Parameters:
      pts - List of Geodetic2DPoint objects to use as Ring vertices
      validateTopology - boolean flag indicating that Ring topology should be validated
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - error if point list is empty or number of points is less than 4

    • LinearRing

      public LinearRing(Geodetic2DBounds box)
      This Constructor takes a bounding box and initializes a LinearRing Object for it. This ring points will be clockwise direction starting at the south-west corner.
      Parameters:
      box - the bounding box to represent as a ring, never null.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the bounding box is null, a point or a line

      protected void computeBoundingBox()
      Description copied from class: Geometry
      Compute a bounding box from the data for this geometry object. This is called if Geometry.getBoundingBox() is called and the bounding box is not set. This may be true if the object is initialized or if the object is copied over a network connection or has been otherwise serialized.
      Specified by:

    • clippedAtDateLine

      public boolean clippedAtDateLine()
      This predicate method is used to tell if this Ring has positive Longitude points that are part of segments which are clipped at the International Date Line (IDL) (+/- 180 Longitude). If so, -180 values may need to be written as +180 by export methods to satisfy GIS tools that expect this.
      Returns:
      boolean value indicating whether this ring is clipped at the IDL

    • clockwise

      public boolean clockwise()
      This predicate method tests whether this Ring object is in clockwise point order or not.
      Returns:
      true if this Ring's points are in clockwise order, false otherwise

    • contains

      public boolean contains(Geodetic2DPoint p)
      This predicate method determines whether this Ring contains a test point, by counting line crossings and determining their parity. This version of the algorithm adapted from code written by W. Randolph Franklin.
      Parameters:
      p - Geodetic2DPoint test point
      Returns:
      true if the test point is inside of this ring of points

    • overlaps

      public boolean overlaps(LinearRing that)
      This predicate method determines whether this Ring overlaps another Ring (that).
      Parameters:
      that - Ring object to test for overlapping with this Ring
      Returns:
      true if this Ring overlaps the specified Ring 'that'

    • contains

      public boolean contains(LinearRing that)
      This predicate method determines whether this Ring completely contains another Ring (that). It first makes sure that no pair of line segments between the two rings intersect, and if that is true, it then checks to see if a single point of the proposed inner Ring is in fact inside this Ring.
      Parameters:
      that - Ring object to test for containment within this Ring
      Returns:
      true if this Ring completely contains the specified Ring 'that'

    • intersects

      public boolean intersects(LinearRing that)
      This predicate method determines whether the specified Ring (that) has any area in common with this Ring, that is, whether they intersect or not.
      Parameters:
      that - Ring to test for intersection with this Ring
      Returns:
      true if the specified Ring intersects this Ring
